DGACM.relevance_comment: Explicitly affirms that the Department for General Assembly and Conference Management (DGACM) is responsible for implementation of policy, formulation of standards and guidelines, overseeing and coordinating United Nations conference services and overall management of resources — i.e., it confirms DGACM’s programmatic mandate described in the PPB (conference services, standards, integrated global management).

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue to explore technological and other innovations to advance effectiveness and efficiency in conference services and to report — a task DGACM implements in the PPB via its Global Innovation and Data Analytics Service and by leading enterprise IT projects (e.g., gMeets, gDoc, gText, eAPG).

Requests the Secretary‑General to ensure that new modules (e‑deleGATE, iGov, gData, gDoc, gMeets, gText) are implemented as enterprise systems and to report on operations/maintenance/harmonization — DGACM is the entity that develops, maintains and deploys these systems per the PPB, so this directs work that DGACM implements.

Requests the Secretary‑General to ensure that measures taken by DGACM to seek evaluation by Member States of conference service quality provide equal opportunities in the six official languages and to report — DGACM runs the global survey and client‑satisfaction processes described in the PPB, so this directs SG action that DGACM implements operationally.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue to explore best practices and techniques in client satisfaction evaluations, to seek higher response rates and to report — DGACM leads client satisfaction evaluation (global survey) in the PPB and would implement these initiatives.

Requests the Secretary‑General to intensify exploration of innovative ways to systematically capture and analyse feedback from Member States and Chairs/Secretaries of committees and to report — DGACM is responsible in the PPB for client feedback mechanisms (global survey, analytics) and would carry out such systematic capture/analysis.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue to seek evaluation of conference services at least once a year, guaranteeing Member States may present evaluations in any of the six official languages — DGACM operates these evaluation forums and the multilingual arrangements as detailed in the PPB, so this directs activity DGACM implements.

Requests the Secretary‑General to keep the General Assembly and the Committee on Conferences apprised of progress made in ensuring integrated global management and to provide up‑to‑date information on new initiatives — integrated global management and related reporting are functions DGACM carries out (PPB describes DGACM’s role in integrated global management and reporting).

Requests the Secretary‑General to ensure consistent and effective implementation of the terms of reference for the Coordinator for Multilingualism and to report — the Coordinator resides within DGACM per the PPB and DGACM implements Secretariat‑wide multilingualism coordination, so this directs work DGACM leads.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue to take actions for effective implementation of timely issuance of documents for the Fifth Committee, taking into account stakeholders’ responsibilities, and to report — DGACM’s documentation subprogrammes are responsible for timely simultaneous issuance per the PPB and would implement these actions.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue to take action on providing timely and simultaneous issuance of documents in all six official languages — this is a direct operational requirement that maps to DGACM’s documentation and publication responsibilities as described in the PPB.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue to seek ways to promote workload‑sharing among the four main duty stations and to report — workload‑sharing of translation/editing/précis‑writing is explicitly managed by DGACM in the PPB (global management of documentation), so this directs DGACM implementation via SG coordination.

Requests the Secretary‑General to enforce the slotting system more rigorously through a dedicated focus such as the interdepartmental task force on documentation (noting the task force is chaired by DGACM), to report and urges author departments to adhere to deadlines — DGACM chairs the task force and is assigned the operational role in the PPB to facilitate submission and manage slotting, so this directs implementation by DGACM.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue efforts to upload important older UN documents onto the UN website in all six official languages on a priority basis — digitization, publishing and online distribution are DGACM functions (subprogramme 4 and documentation services) in the PPB, so this directs activity DGACM carries out.

Requests the Secretary‑General to take all measures necessary to ensure that the digitization of key documents in the Dag Hammarskjöld Library and main duty stations is completed in a timely manner — DGACM’s publishing and document management responsibilities in the PPB map to implementing digitization and distribution, so this directs DGACM‑implemented work.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue to maintain and update the global terminology portal (UNTERM) to ensure its availability to staff, Member States and the public — maintenance of UNTERM is a DGACM deliverable in the PPB (Subprogramme 3), so this directs activity DGACM performs.

Requests the Secretary‑General, as Chair of the UN System Chief Executives Board for Coordination, to continue to invite heads of participating funds, programmes and agencies to consider using official UN terminology and to report — DGACM/Coordinator for Multilingualism is the Secretariat‑wide lead for terminology (PPB) and would implement this outreach in collaboration with SG offices, so this mandates work DGACM undertakes.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue efforts to develop recruitment, subcontracting and outreach policies relating to the pool of language professionals and to report — DGACM’s PPB includes recruitment, outreach to universities and subcontracting strategies (competitive exams, outsourcing), so this directs DGACM‑implemented actions.

Requests the Secretary‑General to ensure that all language services are given equal treatment and provided with equally favourable working conditions and resources — DGACM is responsible for Secretariat‑wide multilingualism coordination and for standards across duty stations in the PPB, so this is a mandate DGACM implements under SG direction.

Requests the Secretary‑General to take measures to ensure equal treatment of all six official languages, to address workload inequities arising from staffing structures and language specificities, and to report — DGACM’s PPB explicitly covers workload‑equity, staffing and technology adaptation across languages, so this directs DGACM implementation.

Reiterates the need for the Secretary‑General to ensure compatibility of technologies used in all duty stations and that they are user‑friendly in all official languages — DGACM’s Global Innovation and Data Analytics Service is tasked in the PPB to develop/maintain enterprise systems and ensure multilingual user‑friendliness, so this directs DGACM work.

Welcomes development of the computer‑assisted and machine translation system (eLUNa) and requests the Secretary‑General to report on updates (including cost‑benefit and quality control) — eLUNa is a DGACM tool referenced in the PPB (documentation/translation innovation), so this instructs activity DGACM implements and reports on.

Requests the Secretary‑General to intensify efforts aimed at filling vacancies in the language services (translation and interpretation) in a timely manner and to report — DGACM is responsible for recruitment planning and competitive examinations in the PPB and would implement efforts to fill vacancies.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue efforts to address recruitment and retention of staff in language services and to ensure strategic workforce planning — this maps directly to DGACM’s workforce planning, training and recruitment activities described in the PPB.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue efforts to hold competitive examinations for recruitment of language staff sufficiently in advance to fill vacancies and to inform the Assembly of efforts — DGACM conducts competitive recruitment examinations per the PPB, so this mandates DGACM action.

Requests the Secretary‑General to enhance access to competitive examinations (e.g., remote exams, closer sites) and to report — DGACM’s PPB includes improving recruitment methods and remote competitive examinations, so this directs DGACM implementation.

Stresses need to ensure highest quality of contractual and in‑house translation and interpretation and requests the Secretary‑General to report on measures taken — DGACM’s documentation quality‑control frameworks and interpreter management are core PPB functions, so this directs DGACM activities.

Reiterates request that the Secretary‑General provide, at all duty stations, adequate staff at the appropriate level to ensure quality control for external translation and freelance interpretation — DGACM is responsible for staffing and quality control arrangements across duty stations in the PPB, so this is an implementation mandate for DGACM.

Requests the Secretary‑General to apply common standards for quality control of documents processed by external translators at all four duty stations and to report — DGACM’s PPB describes strengthening performance management and quality assurance mechanisms for documentation and external processing, so this directs tasks DGACM will implement.

Requests the Secretary‑General to ensure experience, lessons learned and best practices in quality control are shared among duty stations and regional commissions — DGACM coordinates workload‑sharing, standards and best practice exchange in the PPB, so this mandates DGACM action.

Requests the Secretary‑General to ensure effective application of globally standardized performance indicators and costing models at the four main duty stations — DGACM is responsible for implementing standardized performance indicators and costing models as reflected in the PPB (reporting and harmonization), so this directs DGACM implementation.

Encourages the Secretary‑General to apply similar quality‑control measures for interpretation services, in particular freelance interpreters — DGACM manages interpretation quality and freelance interpreter arrangements in the PPB, so this directs DGACM‑implemented activity.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue to improve the internship programme, including through partnerships that promote the official languages — DGACM’s PPB includes traineeships, internships and outreach to universities as recruitment and capacity‑building measures, so this directs DGACM implementation.

Welcomes memorandums of understanding between the Organization and universities to strengthen language training and requests the Secretary‑General to continue assessing appropriate number of MOUs — DGACM leads outreach and university partnerships in the PPB and would implement expansion/assessment of MOUs.

Requests the Secretary‑General to make further efforts to promote outreach programmes (traineeships, internships), introduce innovative methods to increase awareness (including partnerships with Member States and language institutions) and to report — DGACM’s PPB includes outreach and traineeship initiatives to replenish language capacity, so this is a mandate DGACM implements.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue to improve and strengthen initiatives related to training and replenishing the Organization’s language capacity (including outreach programmes) — DGACM is responsible for training, learning and replenishing language capacity in its PPB and will implement these initiatives.

Requests the Secretary‑General to continue to liaise with permanent missions to identify outreach opportunities with universities and language centres worldwide to ensure availability of high‑quality language services — DGACM conducts liaison and outreach to universities and Missions per the PPB, so this directs activity DGACM carries out.
